properties.short_description: Early season shred sessions start in Big Blue with a variety of jibs, jumps and snow features.

long_description.what: A mix of features from jibs to jumps and plenty of creativity. Big Blue is the first park to open, it's a riders dream come true when opening day hits each November. Located on the west side of South 40, Big Blue is shreddable from either the Accelerator Quad, or for hot laps from the Castle Peak Quad. This front and center Woodward Mountain Park keeps the set-up fresh by combining street rails with endless transitions, jumps, spines and more. Big Blue closes mid-season, but reopens in the spring for endless warm sunshiney days.
long_description.where: Riders left side of South 40. Accessible from Castle Peak Quad or Accelerator Quad.

properties.name: Big Blue Park

long_description.what: 16ft mini pipe for training and pipe hot laps. Whether it's airing out for the first time or nailing that handplant, the 16-ft mini-pipe is the perfect place to dial in your tricks as guests watch in awe from the Accelerator lift.
long_description.who: Skiers and riders looking to get transition and practice their pipe lines
long_description.when: You're looking for the ultimate good time

properties.short_description: The original terrain park turned Woodward Mountain Park.

long_description.what: Jibassic is a park riders paradise, with 40+ features to shred daily. Back in the day Boreal Mountain created one of the first terrain parks in the industry, introducing Jibassic Park in 1992 — a park riders paradise. After a brief hiatus, Jibassic was brought back to life in the 18/19 season returning to its roots and offering up jibs on jibs on jibs for riders to rip all day long. Look for this OG park on the riders left of the Accelerator lift.
long_description.who: The jibber, rail-hitter, or anyone looking to get technical on man-made features
long_description.where: Between Accelerator and 49er, the entrance is tucked in the trees.

properties.name: Jibassic Park

properties.short_description: The Pacific High Line is built for sending — and sending ‘er big.

long_description.what: This traditional terrain park is THE spot in Tahoe for shredders. Located east of the Accelerator lift, the Pacific High Line park is the center of attention at Boreal. Built with progression in mind, jumps range from XS to L with each designed to allow riders of all abilities to safely clear the deck. Always make sure you’re comfortable with speed before you paddle out to the lineup. Afterwards, the jump zone flows into a jib garden, making Pacific High Line nothing short of awesome.
long_description.when: Big features are your bread and butter

properties.name: Pacific Highline

properties.short_description: A perfect introduction to freestyle terrain with ride-on features.

long_description.what: A skier or rider's first intro to a lift-accessed terrain park to develop the building blocks of terrain riding. By creating mini versions of rails, boxes and jumps the Woodward Progression Park provides a non-intimidating atmosphere for riders and skiers to begin developing new park skills. A perfect confidence builder for the soon-to-be jibber.
long_description.where: East of Castle Peak Quad on Kiss-A-Bear Trail
long_description.when: The next step up from Start Park

properties.name: Progression Park

properties.short_description: NOW OPEN! Acess it off California Cruiser or Castle Peak.

long_description.what: A fun trail for families. Cruise through for a non-intimidating atmosphere of small berms, banked turns and laughs. The zone provides little skiers and riders or beginners a change to develop their skills by introducing varying terrain.
long_description.where: Situated in the trees, east of California Cruiser, near Adventure Trail.
long_description.when: You're ready to get cruise-y through berms, banked turns and more.

properties.name: Woodward Family Cross

properties.short_description: Creative, progressive and cutting edge, Peace Park is for the people.

long_description.what: A collab between Danny Davis, and the Woodward Tahoe park crew. Peace Park is the ultimate in fun, flow and freestyle terrain. Woodward Peace Park is built for intermediate and advanced riders, but with a little something for everyone. Transcending standard slopestyle and halfpipes, there's more flow, transition, room to breathe, and options for creative expression. Snow shredders on snowboards and skis are all welcome. Mid-season, Peace Park is the place to hang with your friends slashing berms or bobbing thru the rhythm sections, under the Lost Dutchman chairlift. Peace Park is perfect groups of multi-level skiers and riders who want to stay together during the day, yet still have a wide variety of terrain to enjoy.
long_description.who: Riders looking to express their creativity
long_description.where: Lost Dutchman Zone, but open for 2021 on Pacific High Line (temporary)
long_description.when: You don't want to go big, you just want to have fun with your crew

properties.name: Woodward Peace Park

long_description.what: First-timers and beginners start their progression journey in our Start Park where they are introduced to terrain-based learning. By introducing sculpted snow features, like bumps and berms, the Start Park uses terrain-based learning to give skiers and snowboarders to their first taste of transitional park riding.
long_description.where: Base Area, East of California Cruiser
long_description.when: When you're ready to kick start your snow sliding experience, or learn the basics of terrain park riding.
